dialogue: Here are three bars showing different fractions. Which sequence puts them in order from smallest to largest?
prompt: Which option shows these fractions in order from smallest to largest?

workspace.description: Bar divided into tenths with 1 interval shaded
Bar divided into tenths with 4 intervals shaded
Bar divided into tenths with 6 intervals shaded

correct_answer.context: 1/10 is the smallest (fewest shaded parts), 4/10 is in the middle, and 6/10 is the largest (most shaded parts)

success_path_dialogue: That's right. They're all in order now.

steps.dialogue: Not quite. Look at how many parts are shaded in each bar. The smallest has the fewest shaded parts.

Let's think about this together. When fractions have the same denominator, we can compare by looking at the numerators. The bar with 1 shaded part shows the smallest fraction, then 4 shaded parts, then 6 shaded parts shows the largest. That tells us the order from smallest to largest.

Let me walk you through ordering these fractions. All three bars are divided into tenths, so we can compare them by counting the shaded parts. Bar 1 has 1 shaded part, which is 1/10. Bar 2 has 4 shaded parts, which is 4/10. Bar 3 has 6 shaded parts, which is 6/10. The smallest fraction is the one with the fewest shaded parts - that's 1/10. Next comes 4/10 with more shaded parts. The largest is 6/10 with the most shaded parts. So the order from smallest to largest is 1/10, 4/10, 6/10. That's how we order fractions with the same denominator - we compare the numerators to see which has fewer or more parts.
